title: 103_s1049
content:
The Act titled "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" recognizes the scientific and environmental significance of Lechuguilla Cave and other caves in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. It aims to protect these caves from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS

Cave protection area refers to lands within a specified map area. Secretary means the Secretary of the Interior. Other terms have the same meaning as in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976.

SEC. 4. LAND WITHDRAWAL. (a) Withdrawal.--Approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area are withdrawn from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws, including mining and material disposal laws, and mineral leasing and geothermal leasing laws.
(b) Land Description.--The lands are depicted on the map entitled "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Area" dated April 1993.
(c) Publication, Filing, Correction, and Inspection. The Lechuguilla Cave Protection Area encompasses approximately 6,280 acres of public lands withdrawn from various laws, including mining and leasing laws. The lands are described in a map filed in April 1993 for publication and inspection by the Secretary. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description and map of the lands withdrawn under the Act for the House and Senate committees. The map and legal description will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act. The map and legal description of withdrawn lands will be provided to the House and Senate committees for public inspection. The Secretary may correct errors in the map and legal description. The withdrawn public lands will be managed by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management, in accordance with relevant laws. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary shall not permit new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to prevent adverse impacts on cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The Secretary can suspend activities on mineral or geothermal leases to protect cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park until a decision on drilling is made. The Secretary can suspend drilling activities in the cave protection area until a decision is made, lasting up to 12 months from the enactment of the Act. During the prohibition period, the Secretary can suspend drilling activities in the cave protection area for up to 12 months. After this period, new drilling may be permitted or prohibited based on agreements with leaseholders. During the specified period, the Secretary will negotiate with leaseholders to terminate leases or impose restrictions on activities to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The Secretary will negotiate with leaseholders to terminate leases or impose restrictions to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, considering the value of oil and gas resources that owners will not be allowed to recover. The Secretary will seek agreements with leaseholders to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, considering the value of oil and gas resources that owners will not be allowed to recover. If no agreement is reached, the Secretary will take appropriate steps to safeguard the caves. The Secretary will take steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, which may include acquiring lands covered by leases or other interests. The Secretary will protect Lechuguilla Cave and other cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park by acquiring lands within the cave protection area, which will be managed according to relevant laws. The Secretary will manage lands within the cave protection area according to relevant laws, seeking cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other landowners to further protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources. The Secretary will seek cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other landowners to implement restrictions on land use within the cave protection area to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park based on relevant scientific analysis. Access limitations may be imposed to safeguard these resources. The Secretary may limit access to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, including prohibiting the removal of mineral, geological, or cave resources for scientific purposes. If existing laws are insufficient, the Secretary must inform the Committee on Natural Resources of the House. The Secretary may limit access to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. If additional authority is needed, the Secretary will inform the relevant committees in Congress. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under other laws.
